title: RS21539
content: Vacancies in Congress occur when a Senator or Representative dies, resigns, declines to serve, or is expelled. The Constitution requires special elections to fill vacancies, but the Senate allows for temporary appointments by state governors. Most Senate vacancies are filled by gubernatorial appointment until a special election can be held, except in Oregon and Wisconsin where vacancies must be filled by election. In the House of Representatives, vacancies are filled by special elections. Vacancies in the Senate are filled by election, while House vacancies are filled by special election. Special elections are scheduled based on the timing of the vacancy, with some states holding special elections on the same day as regular elections. Winners of special elections are considered incumbent Representatives for seniority and office selection purposes. In the U.S. House of Representatives, vacancies are filled by special elections. In California, a special primary election was scheduled to fill the vacancy left by Rep. Robert T. Matsui's death before the convening of the 109th Congress. If no candidate receives a majority of votes, a special runoff election will be held. On January 4, 2003, Ed Case won a special election to fill the vacancy left by the death of Rep. In Texas, a special election was held on May 3, 2003, with 17 candidates from various parties on the ballot. A runoff election took place on June 3, 2003, as no candidate received a majority of the votes.
